questions.question: 1. How do you describe an array?

answers.a: Data structure having linear access time
answers.b: Data structure containing elements of similar types in contiguous storage
answers.c: A container of unique elements of similar types
answers.d: Data structure containing elements located in various locations memory which may or may not be contiguous

explanations.a: Access time in an array is constant, not linear.
explanations.c: Elements in an array may or may not be unique.
explanations.d: Array always stores its elements in contiguous memory locations.

questions.question: 2. What is the time complexity of traversing through all the elements in an array?

explanations.c: To traverse through all the elements in an array, one needs to visit all the elements at least once. Hence the time complexity is O(N) i.e. the size of the array.

questions.question:
3. Let us consider the following code:
int a = 0, b[N];
for (i = 0; i < M; i++) {
    a+=i;
}
for (i = 0; i < N; i++) {
    scanf(\“%d\”, &b[i]);
    a+=b[i];
}
What is the space and time complexity of the above code?

explanations.d: Since a is a variable for integer input, hence it will occupy space for just one integer. Whereas b is an array of length N, thus it will occupy space for N integers. Since both loops will be executed one after the other, hence the resulting time complexity will be the sum of iterations of both loops i.e. M+N.

questions.question:
4. Let us consider following four arrays:
A = [9, 5, 11, 25, 7, 35]
B = [1, 2, 9, 15, 27]
C = [29, 27, 27, 18, 4, 2]
D = [1, 8, 2, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]
Which of the arrays are sorted?

explanations.c: B is sorted in ascending order, whereas C is sorted in descending order.

questions.question: 5. If for large inputs, X is a better choice than Y, then:

answers.a: Y is asymptotically more efficient than X
answers.b: X is asymptotically more efficient than Y
answers.c: X and Y are equivalently efficient

explanations.a: Incorrect, Y cannot be more efficient as X is a better choice
explanations.b: Since X is asymptotically more efficient than Y, hence X will perform better in case of large inputs
explanations.c: Since X is getting preferred, hence X and Y cannot be equivalent
